column1: Lansing  is the capital of the U.S. state of Michigan. It is mostly in Ingham County
column2: although portions of the city extend west into Eaton County and north into Clinton County. The 2010 Census placed the city's population at 114
column4: making it the fifth largest city in Michigan. The population of its Metropolitan Statistical Area (MSA) was 464
column6: while the even larger Combined Statistical Area (CSA) population
column7: which includes Shiawassee County
column8: was 534
column9: 684. It was named the new state capital of Michigan in 1847
column10: ten years after Michigan became a state.

column3: is an important center for educational
column4: cultural
column6: commercial
column7: and industrial functions. Neighboring East Lansing is home to Michigan State University
column8: a public research university with an enrollment of more than 50
column9: 000.  The area features two medical schools
column10: one veterinary school
column12: and two law schools.  It is the site of the Michigan State Capitol
column16: the Library of Michigan and Historical Center
column17: and headquarters of four national insurance companies.

column1: Lansing is the only U.S. state capital (among the 47 located in counties) that is not also a county seat. The seat of government of Ingham County is Mason
column2: but the county maintains some offices in Lansing.

column1: The first recorded person of European descent to travel through the area that is now Lansing was British fur trader Hugh Heward and his French-Canadian team on April 24
column2: 1790 while canoeing the Grand River. The land that was to become Lansing was surveyed as "Township 4 North Range 2 West" in February 1827 in what was then dense forest. It was the last of the county's townships to be surveyed
column3: and the land was not offered for sale until October 1830. There would be no roads to this area for decades to come.

column1: In the winter of 1835 and early 1836
column2: two brothers from New York plotted the area now known as REO Town just south of downtown Lansing and named it "Biddle City". This land lay in a floodplain and was underwater during the majority of the year. Nevertheless
column3: the brothers went back to Lansing
column4: New York
column5: to sell plots for the town that did not exist. They told the New Yorkers this new "city" had an area of 65 blocks
column6: a church and a public and academic square. 16 men bought plots in the nonexistent city
column7: and upon reaching the area later that year found they had been scammed. Many in the group
column8: too disappointed to stay
column9: ended up settling around what is now metropolitan Lansing. Those who stayed quickly renamed the area "Lansing Township" in honor of their home village in New York.The settlement of fewer than 20 people would remain dormant until the winter of 1847 when the state constitution required the capital be moved from Detroit to a more central and safer location in the state's interior; many were concerned about Detroit's proximity to British-controlled Canada
column10: which had captured Detroit in the War of 1812. The United States had recaptured the city in 1813
column11: but these events led to the dire need to have the center of government relocate from hostile British territory. There was also concern with Detroit's strong influence over Michigan politics
column12: being the state's largest city as well as the capital city.During the multi-day session to determine a new location for the state capital
column17: lobbied hard to win this designation. Unable to publicly reach a consensus because of constant political wrangling
column18: the Michigan House of Representatives privately chose the Township of Lansing out of frustration. When announced
column19: many present openly laughed that such an insignificant settlement was now Michigan's capital. Two months later
column20: Governor William L. Greenly signed into law the act of the legislature making Lansing Township the state capital.

column1: With the announcement that Lansing Township had been made the capital
column2: the small village quickly transformed into the seat of state government. The legislature gave the settlement the temporary name of the "Town of Michigan". In April 1848
column3: the legislature then gave the settlement the name of "Lansing". Within months after it became the capital city
column4: individual settlements began to develop along three key points along the Grand River in the township:

column3: was the oldest of the three villages. It was home to the first house built in Lansing in 1843 by pioneer James Seymour and his family. Lower Town began to develop in 1847 with the completion of the Franklin Avenue (now Grand River Avenue) covered bridge over the Grand River.

column2: where present-day REO Town stands at the confluence of the Grand River and the Red Cedar River. It began to take off in 1847 when the Main Street Bridge was constructed over the Grand River. This village's focal point was the Benton House
column3: a 4-story hotel which opened in 1848. It was the first brick building in Lansing and was later razed in 1900.

was the last of the three villages to develop in 1848 with the completion of the Michigan Avenue bridge across the Grand River and the completion of the temporary capitol building which sat where Cooley Law School stands today on Capitol Avenue between Allegan and Washtenaw Streets
column4: and finally the relocation of the post office to the village in 1851. This area would grow to become larger than the other two villages up and down river. For a brief time the combined villages were referred to as "Michigan" but was officially named Lansing in 1848.In 1859
column5: the settlement having grown to nearly 3
column6: 000 and encompassing about seven square miles (18 km2) in area was incorporated as a city. The boundaries of the original city were Douglas Avenue to the north
column7: Wood and Regent streets to the east
column8: Mount Hope Avenue to the south
column9: and Jenison Avenue to the west. These boundaries would remain until 1916. Lansing began to grow steadily over the next two decades with the completion of the railroads through the city
column10: a plank road
column11: and the completion of the current capitol building in 1878.

column1: Most of what is known as Lansing today is the result of the city becoming an industrial powerhouse which began with the founding of Olds Motor Vehicle Company in August 1897. The company went through many changes
column3: between its founding to 1905 when founder Ransom E. Olds started his new REO Motor Car Company
column4: which would last in Lansing for another 70 years. Olds would be joined by the less successful Clarkmobile around 1903. Over the next decades
column5: the city would be transformed into a major American industrial center for the manufacturing of automobiles and parts
column6: among other industries. The city also continued to grow in area. By 1956
column7: the city had grown to 15 square miles (39 km2)
column8: and doubled in size over the next decade to its current size of roughly 33 square miles (85 km2).Today
column9: the city's economy is diversified among government service
column10: healthcare

column1: The Kerns Hotel fire on 11 December 1934 was the deadliest in the city's history. Perhaps thirty-four people died in the fire
column2: although the hotel register was also destroyed making an exact count impossible.

column3: a 12-year-old
column5: 000-pound female dancing elephant named Rajje (alternately reported as Raji and Little Rajjee
column6: among other variations) rebelled against her trainer during a performance in a shopping-center circus near what was then Logan Street and Holmes Road in Lansing
column7: and escaped into the streets
column8: aggravated by the frenzied pursuit of nearly 4
column9: 000 local residents. The incident ended with the shooting of the elephant by Lansing police. Provoked by the growing crowd
column10: Rajje's rampage took her through the men's wear
column11: sporting goods and gift departments of a local Arlan's discount store before leading police on a two-mile chase in which she knocked down and injured a 67-year-old man
column13: and caused thousands of dollars in damage before being killed.

column3: as shouting at the scene
column4: "Damn these people [...] They wouldn't leave her alone."The incident was widely reported
column5: including a photospread in Life. While the Lansing State Journal coverage stressed the danger of the incident
column6: the Detroit Free Press noted that witnesses cried out "Murderers! Murderers!" as police fired eight shots.Author Nelson Algren cites the injustice and sad end of the pursuit of "Raji
column7: the Pixie-Eared Elephant" in continuity with the ambush of Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow in his introduction to a 1968 biography of the outlaws. Then teenage Lansing residents who had goaded the elephant on recalled the incident with sober regret in a local newspaper retrospective in 2011.

column1: Lansing is the centerpiece of a region of Michigan known as Mid-Michigan or Central Michigan.
According to the United States Census Bureau

column1: Lansing is located in the south-central part of the Lower Peninsula of Michigan
column2: where the Grand River meets the Red Cedar River. The city occupies most of what had formerly been part of Lansing Charter Township. It has also annexed adjacent tracts of land in Delta Charter Township and Windsor Township in Eaton County to the west
column3: Delhi Charter Township in Ingham County to the south
column4: and in DeWitt Charter Township in Clinton County to the north. The city also controls three non-contiguous tracts of land through 425 Agreements (conditional land transfer agreements) with Meridian Charter Township
column6: and Alaiedon Township in Ingham County to the southeast.

column1: Lansing elevations range between 890 feet (271 m) above sea level on the far south side of Lansing along Northrup Street near the Cedar Street intersection

column3: flows through downtown Lansing
column4: and the Red Cedar River

column12: and fishermen. Michigan State University Sailing Club and the Lansing Sailing Club are located on Lake Lansing

column1: Lansing has a Midwestern humid continental climate (Köppen Dfb/Dfa) that is influenced by the Great Lakes
column2: and is part of USDA Hardiness zone 5b. Winters are cold with moderate to heavy snowfall
column3: while summers are very warm and humid. The monthly daily average temperature in July is 71.5 °F (21.9 °C)
column4: while the same figure for January is 23.4 °F (−4.8 °C); the annual mean is 48.21 °F (9.01 °C). On average
column5: temperatures reach or exceed 90 °F (32.2 °C) on 8.8 days of the year and drop to or below 0 °F (−17.8 °C) on 10.5 nights. Precipitation is generally greatest during summer but still frequent and significant in winter. Snowfall
column6: which normally occurs from November to April
column7: averages 51.1 inches (130 cm) per season
column8: significantly less than areas to the west such as Grand Rapids as Lansing is relatively immune to lake-effect snows; seasonal snowfall has historically ranged from 16.6 in (42 cm) in 1863−64 to 97.2 in (247 cm) in 1880−81. The highest and lowest officially recorded temperatures were 103 °F (39 °C) on July 6
column10: and −37 °F (−38 °C) on February 2
column12: with the last −20 °F (−29 °C) or colder reading occurred on February 27
column13: 1994; the record low maximum is −4 °F (−20 °C) on January 22
column17: the record high minimum is 78 °F (26 °C) on August 1
column19: 1942. Freezing temperatures in June are exceedingly rare and have not occurred in July or August since the 19th century; on average
column20: they arrive on October 4 and depart on May 7
column21: allowing a growing season of 149 days. The average window for measurable snow (≥0.1 in or 0.25 cm) is November 4 thru April 6.

column1: The city's downtown is dominated by state government buildings
column2: especially the State Capitol; but downtown has also experienced recent growth in new restaurants
column3: retail stores and residential developments. Downtown Lansing has a historic city market that is one of the oldest continuously operating farmers' markets in the United States. Upriver and north of downtown is historic Old Town Lansing with many architecturally significant buildings dating to the mid-19th century. Directly south of downtown on the other side of I-496 along Washington Avenue lies "REO Town"
column4: the birthplace of the automobile in the United States
column5: is where Ransom Eli Olds built factories along Washington Avenue. Ransom Eli Olds' home
column6: which once overlooked the factories along Washington Avenue
column7: was displaced by I-496.

column1: Lansing is administered under a mayor–council government
column2: more specifically a strong mayor form in which the mayor is the city's chief executive officer. The mayor is obligated to appoint department heads (subject to council approval)
column3: and draft and administer a city budget among other responsibilities. The mayor may also veto legislation from council
column4: though the veto can be overridden by an affirmative vote of two-thirds of the council. The mayor and city clerk are elected at-large every four years.

column1: The city council is the legislative body of the city and consists of eight members.  Four members are elected from four single-member districts using the first-past-the-post method in the city's wards
column2: and four members are elected at-large using the block voting method. Members of the council serve staggered four-year terms. Half the council is up for election every two years
column3: including two ward seats and two at-large seats. At its first meeting of the year
column4: the council chooses from amongst its members a president and vice president. The president is the council's presiding officer
column5: and also chooses the chairs of council committees. In the absence of the president and vice president
column6: the city clerk chairs the council.

column1: The city largely supports the Democratic Party.  It has not had a Republican mayor in office since 1993 when then-Democratic state representative David Hollister defeated incumbent Mayor Jim Crawford
column2: who had formerly served as a Republican member on the Ingham County Board of Commissioners. However
column3: all city elections are held on an officially nonpartisan basis.Since given the ability to do so by the state in 1964
column4: the city has levied an income tax of 1 percent on residents. 0.5 percent on non-residents

column1: Sparrow Hospital is a 740-bed hospital affiliated with Michigan State University and its College of Human Medicine and College of Osteopathic Medicine. In February 2009 it was announced that Sparrow and MSU formalized their partnership to increase research and faculty recruitment. Sparrow Hospital is the Regional Center for pediatrics
column3: including radiation therapy
column4: trauma care

column15: and emergency treatment is more than any other hospital in mid-Michigan. The Sparrow Health System Laboratory performs over 3 million tests per year
column17: which include four remote testing facilities and thirteen patient service centers. Sparrow Hospital is certified as a Level I Trauma Center by the American College of Surgeons. In May 2009 Sparrow announced that it now has its own helicopter service based at its downtown Lansing hospital's new $2.5 million helipad. The addition is expected to increase helicopter patient transport to the hospital from four a month to 400 a year.

column1: McLaren–Greater Lansing Hospital is also a university affiliated teaching hospital. MSU has the largest land campus in the United States and is home to several nationally and internationally recognized academic and research oriented programs. Michigan State offers over 200 programs of study and is home to fourteen different degree-granting schools and colleges including two medical schools
column6: a law school

Michigan State University is the oldest agricultural college in the United States. The MSU School of Criminal Justice is the oldest continuous degree granting criminal justice program in the nation. column1: Capital Area Transportation Authority (CATA) provides public transit bus service to the Lansing-East Lansing Metropolitan area on 33 routes. CATA boasts the second highest ridership in the state of Michigan after Detroit with 53
column4: 339 rides in fiscal year 2008. CATA also provides paratransit services through Spec-Tran and the "Night Owl." Also
column5: the "Entertainment Express" (CATA route 4) runs Thursday through Saturday from 7 pm to 2 am connecting downtown Lansing's and East Lansing's entertainment districts. CATA won APTA's America's Best Transit Award in the medium-size category (4–30 million rides) in 2007. CATA has two transportation centers (CTC)
column6: one in downtown Lansing and one on the campus of Michigan State University. In 2010
column7: a study was conducted to consider ways of enhancing the Lansing-to-East Lansing route (currently known as Route 1)
column8: with options including enhanced bus service
column9: single-car trolley service and light rail service. (Heavy rail was eliminated as an option early in the process
column10: with enhanced bus service eventually winning out.)
